title: deck
text:
source

Deck

 Deck ()

A deck of 32 Cards, not including jokers and the number from 2 to 9
When we initially create a Deck of Cards, it contains all 32 cards.

deck = Deck()
deck

J♤; Q♤; K♤; A♤; 7♤; 8♤; 9♤; 10♤; J♡; Q♡; K♡; A♡; 7♡; 8♡; 9♡; 10♡; J♢; Q♢; K♢; A♢; 7♢; 8♢; 9♢; 10♢; J♧; Q♧; K♧; A♧; 7♧; 8♧; 9♧; 10♧



card = Card(1,1)
card

J♡


We can check if our Card is in the Deck.

card in deck

True



source


Deck.pop

 Deck.pop (idx=-1)

Remove and return one card from the deck
We can return the card at the last index.

deck.pop()

10♧


The deck should now contain only 31 cards.

len(deck)

31



source


Deck.remove

 Deck.remove (card:nbdev_test.card.Card)

Removes card from the deck or raises exception if it is not there.

deck

J♤; Q♤; K♤; A♤; 7♤; 8♤; 9♤; 10♤; J♡; Q♡; K♡; A♡; 7♡; 8♡; 9♡; 10♡; J♢; Q♢; K♢; A♢; 7♢; 8♢; 9♢; 10♢; J♧; Q♧; K♧; A♧; 7♧; 8♧; 9♧



card = Card(2,3)


deck.remove(card)


card in deck

False

title: card
text:
We put None as the first rank (at index 0) in order to match the index with the rank value. > Remember that the ordering of the ranks is differnet in Schrööm compared to typical card games.
Here are the ranks:
ranks

[None, 'J', 'Q', 'K', 'A', '7', '8', '9', '10']
Here are the suits:
suits

['♤', '♡', '♢', '♧']
source

title: card
text:
Comparison Operators

source

Card.__eq__

 Card.__eq__ (a:__main__.Card)

Return self==value.
Equality, less than and greater than work on the rank and suit indidces:

test_eq(Card(suit=1, rank=3), Card(suit=1, rank=3))
test_ne(Card(suit=2, rank=3), Card(suit=1, rank=3))


source


Card.__lt__

 Card.__lt__ (a:__main__.Card)

Return self<value.

source


Card.__gt__

 Card.__gt__ (a:__main__.Card)

Return self>value.


How it should behave:
When the suit of a is different than the self.suit, Card a is automatically less than self, regardless of the rank.

assert not Card(suit=1, rank=3) < Card(suit=2, rank=3)

If the suits are the same, then the rank decides which one is higher

assert Card(suit=1, rank=3) > Card(suit=1, rank=2)

title: nbdev_test
text: This file will become your README and also the index of your documentation.

title: nbdev_test
text:
Developer Guide
If you are new to using nbdev here are some useful pointers to get you started.

Install nbdev_test in Development mode
# make sure nbdev_test package is installed in development mode
$ pip install -e .

# make changes under nbs/ directory
# ...

# compile to have changes apply to nbdev_test
$ nbdev_prepare

title: nbdev_test
text:
Usage

Installation
Install latest from the GitHub repository:
$ pip install git+https://github.com/janhesse53/nbdev_test.git
or from conda
$ conda install -c janhesse53 nbdev_test
or from pypi
$ pip install nbdev_test


Documentation
Documentation can be found hosted on this GitHub repository’s pages. Additionally you can find package manager specific guidelines on conda and pypi respectively.

title: nbdev_test
text:
How to use
Fill me in please! Don’t forget code examples:

suits

['♤', '♡', '♢', '♧']



ranks

[None, 'J', 'Q', 'K', 'A', '7', '8', '9', '10']



Card(1,3)

K♡
